Situation1: Both have several free evenings this week and can choose any for a date.
Expectation2: Deliver packages on time and to the correct address
Situation2: A medical supply delivery must reach a hospital department on schedule to ensure patient care
Story: I stared at my phone, reading Mia’s message: “Let’s pick a night for our date! We finally have time.” I could almost hear her excitement, and I wanted nothing more than to say yes, to promise her an evening just for us. We’d both been so busy, and she deserved my full attention. But as I started to reply, my work app pinged—a high-priority delivery had just come in. Medical supplies, urgent, for the hospital. The note was clear: “Must arrive on time for patient care.” I felt my chest tighten. If I chose the wrong evening, I might have to leave Mia in the middle of dinner, or worse, cancel last minute. She’d be disappointed, maybe even hurt, and I hated the thought. But if I delayed the delivery, someone’s health could be at risk. I scrolled through our shared calendar, my thumb hovering, torn between the promise I wanted to keep to Mia and the responsibility I owed to my job. The weight of both expectations pressed down on me, and I couldn’t shake the feeling that, no matter what I chose, I’d be letting someone down.
